description: From Latin sȳrinx, from Ancient Greek σῦριγξ (sûrinx, “pipe, tube, channel, fistula”). Doublet of syringe.

examples: Actually, to cut a long story short, he began...well, playing with a rather different sort of pipe. Or syrinx, as we called it. He obviously thought he was alone.

entries.meaning: A narrow channel cut in rock, especially in ancient Egyptian tombs.
(ornithology, zootomy) The voice organ in birds.
examples: The role of the syrinx in psittacine sound production is still under examination, and probably differs from that of songbirds.

entries.meaning: (medicine) Any of several tuboid structures, especially a rare, fluid-filled neuroglial cavity within the spinal cord or in the brain stem.
